subject: fb-ipmi-oem: yosemitev2: Add Ipmi implementation for read post codes
commitMessage:
fb-ipmi-oem: yosemitev2: Add Ipmi implementation for read post codes

Added implementation to handle read post code BIC request from host to BMC and
send the response back to host.

TESTED : Built Facebook YosemiteV2 images and loaded on the target hardware.
Verified all the host's postcodes in BMC.

Signed-off-by: Kumar Thangavel <thangavel.k@hcl.com>
Change-Id: Iee9a224b381db5ab9e244b9ae2999a602e520a36

Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as ad04924d4f42b007c4249d98950e0e60d79d71af by Patrick Williams
Per the design, I would expect the service name to be Raw<N> (and object path to be raw<N> per my comments).  I don't understand why it is "Raw" and "raw1" here.

The postd deamon has single service "xyz.openbmc_project.State.Boot.Raw". it will be Boot.Raw. 
we can have multiple objects raw<1..N>. Will update this
I've left a comment in the design document but I don't think this method should be called 'ReadPostCode' because it is the wrong verb tense.

As I mentioned in the design, I do not think this is necessary.

Are we certain that "channelIdx" == "host ordinal number"?  How?
Why is this a shared pointer and also why to use asio here. you can simply use get default bus
Ack
Do we really need this variant, I guess dbus should take care of this, I might be wrong.

Yes. We need this variant to update the values in the dbus. 
I have Verified without variant, it is not updating values in the dbus.
Please define this as a const variable
Will declare as const variable.
Please avoid hard code value in functional code
Ack
Function name is buffer, but looks like only one postcode at a time on line 84.

Thanks for your comments.
Will update the function name.
this can throw, check for empty
Ack
If only one postcode at a time, can the parameter be just "uint8_t data" ?
yes. Updated with uint8_t.
I meant here to declare this string as a constant like we define #define in C coding.
Ack

We can use the following declarations which are equivalent to #define in C.
1. const std::string dbusObj("/xyz/openbmc_project/state/boot/raw") 
2. const std::string dbusObj = "/xyz/openbmc_project/state/boot/raw". 

constexpr std::string constString = "constString" - This expression is not allowed in C++.
constexpr char constString[] = "constString" - This is allowed in C++.


Could you please suggest to use here the correct declarations.
you can use constexpr char* as used everywhere in code.
Ack
In this line kept as std::string for simple string concatenation with hostIdx.
you can still use const char and apply concatenation. The idea behind using const as single definition and if value or path change then it can be updated at one place only.
Same as above
Ack
Updated with constexpr char* instead of std::string.

data is a uint8_t, so this comparison is checking against zero.

Never use NULL in C++ code.  Use nullptr.  This is a good example why.  You would have gotten a compile error here instead.
Ack
You won't get is_method_error in any case.  You might get an exception on line 113.
Ack
Should it return failure if exception is caught?

Yes. Thanks for your comments.
Updated the patchset.
